prompt.p: Lymphomas are malignancies that affect lymphoid tissue. Different chromosomal translocations and molecular rearrangements influence the pathology and disease prognosis. Lymphomas may be non-Hodgkin's or Hodgkin's.
Which of the following is the chromosome translocation of mantle cell lymphoma?

modalFeedback.p:
Option E (t(11;14) is Correct. Mantle cell lymphomas are due to translocation of t(11;14).
Chromosomal translocations in lymphomas:

ul.li: t(14;18) involves an apoptotic inhibitor oncogene, bcl -2, leading to its over-expression, associated with follicular lymphoma.
t(11;14) leads to over-expression of the cell cycle regulator, bcl- 1, associated with mantle cell lymphoma.
t(8;14) leads to movement of the c-myc proto-oncogene and results in its deregulation, leading to cell proliferation, associated with Burkitt and HIV-infection associated lymphomas.
t(11;18) links an apoptosis inhibitor gene with the MALT1 gene and produces a protein associated with MALT lymphomas.

modalFeedback.p: Option A (t(2;5)) is Incorrect. Translocation of t(2;5) leads to anaplastic large cell lymphoma.
Option B (t(11;18)) is Incorrect. Translocation of t(11;18) leads to MALT lymphoma.
Option C (t(8;14)) is Incorrect. Translocations of t(8;14) are associated with Burkitt and HIV infection associated lymphoma.
Option D (t(14;18)) is Incorrect. Translocation of t(14;18) is associated with follicular lymphoma.
